dialogues.speaker: CREDITS
dialogues.text: Credits are played over Currier and Ives-like winter scen from life in Grand Rapids. It's Christmas morning. -- Two well-bundled youths shovel out a suburban driveway while their father scrapes ice off the family car. -- Youths pelter a passing car with snowballs. Others, mo daring companions, grab onto the car's rear bumper and hi a free ride across the icy roads and past a sign which re "Grand Rapids City Limits." -- Christmas decorations hang from the lamp posts on Monr Avenue. -- Children, dressed in bright parkas, and breathing stea compare their Christmas presents: sleds, skis and a tobog In the b.g., other children speed down Richmond Park Hill -- A woman's distant voice sings an old hymn: "Precious memories, unseen angels,  Sent from somewhere to my soul,  How they linger ever near me,  And the sacred past unfolds.  Precious memories, how they linger,  How they ever flood my soul,  In the stillness of the midnight,  Precious sacred scenes unfold.  Precious father, loving mother,  Fly across the lonely years,  And old home scenes of my childhood  In fond memories appear." END CREDITS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four generations of the Van Dorn family have gathered at family home. A long kitchen leads to the dining area, then to the spac living room. The house is perhaps one hundred years old; deeply varnis woodwork and patterned yellow wallpaper section off the w Apart from several recent tasteless acquisitions (an E-Z lounge chair to replace the old Queen Anne which broke tw Easters ago), the house remains furnished in the style of the previous century. The old dining room table, which  Grandfather Van Dorn built because he was too cheap to bu one, has now become a priceless antique. The rooms are littered with religious calendars, Bibles a plaster-of-Paris plaques bearing such sentiments as "As F Me and My House, We Will Serve the Lord." The oak buffet laden with similar religious knickknacks and chintz. Fram tinted photographs of the family patriarchs are  indiscriminately mixed with newer snapshots of proud fath and high school graduates. The house radiates a sense of continuity. Generations com and go; the family remains. All of life's "old home scene have been played out here: births, deaths, romances,  blasphemies, betrayals. And now the air is again alive wi the sounds of playing children, busy housewives and bicke uncles. The kitchen is crowded with mothers, daughters and aunts. Each has brought a special dish. ANNE DE JONG (nee Van Do thirty-five, supervises the final preparations. One aunt  shows another snapshots of her new grandchild. JAKE VAN DORN, forty, and his brother JOE, fifty, sit at table watching the kitchen activity. The house echoes with small talk:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He got accepted at Grand Valley,  but he'd rather go to Michigan...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Get that pink rot...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...No way Uncle Joe talk me into  cutting celery again this summer.  Rather work in the car wash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the CAMERA TRACKS THROUGH the dining room, it passes a cluster of men standing near the buffet. WES DE JONG and  JOHN VAN DORN, both about forty, casually discuss a  theological point with GRANDFATHER VAN DORN. Across the t a young boy, about eleven, listens with rapt awe. These are men of the soil. Their faces are sun-blotched a weather-beaten. Wes has rolled up the sleeves of his whit shirt; John has switched to a more comfortable plaid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I still say that if a man has  committed the unpardonable sin, he  knows he has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandfather nods head approvingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know about that, John. It  don't seem to account much for God's  grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of grace do you mean,  universal or specific...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long line of folding tables have been set up in the  basement. A mixed assortment of chairs can accommodate th or more persons. A pre-teen daughter helps her mother pla dishes and silverware on the tablecloths. Evergreen branc and red candles decorate the tables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the teenagers have crowded into what was once cal the study, but is now the "television room." KRISTEN VAN  DORN, fourteen, and MARSHA DE JONG, fifteen, are scrunche onto the sofa. Kristen has long blonde hair, a clean Dutc complexion and an unaffected beauty. The girls' legs are  innocently wrapped around each other's. JOE, forty-five, another of the Van Dorn brothers, and a  male cousin about nineteen, are also squeezed on the sofa Young children squat on the floor in front of them. All a watching some inane Christmas variety show. Joe, bored of this tripe, gets up and turns off the set. children wail in unison. "Aw, c'mon, Uncle Joe."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sick of watching this television  stuff. You know who makes it? All  the kids who couldn't get along here.  They go out to California and make  television. I didn't like 'em when  they were here, and I don't like 'em  out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the youngsters reaches over and snaps the set back as Joe leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Joe leaves the den, he passes Jake Van Dorn and Wes De Jong. Unlike his older brother, Jake is not a man of the  soil. He has been to college and runs his own business. H looks well-groomed and comfortable in his navy suit, whit shirt and striped tie. Wes is Jake's brother-in-law and  friend. They get along well enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jake and Wes) Television. If you don't buy one  yourself, the kids go someplace else  and watch. And what do they sell on  television? More televisions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (light) They got to make their money, too,  Joe. Give the kids a break. It's  Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe shrugs and walks into the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne listens as NADINE, her sister-in-law, about forty, a RUTH, her niece, about twenty, help her set out celery an carrot stalks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and they hadn't heard a word from  him before he died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three children, BILL, LENARD and JANE, ages six to ten, w over to the three mothers. Lenard, six years old, wears a blanket over his head in mock Biblical dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aunt Ruth, can we use Timmy for the  Nativity play? We need him to play  the Christ-child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Timmy's only six months old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We won't hurt him. I'm going to be  Joseph, Jane's Mary and Lenard will  be one of the shepherds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill looks at blanket-headed Lenard, who has no idea of w going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't do that. That's blasphemy.  If anybody pretends to be Christ,  it's blasphemy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's only a baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne nods in agreement. Bill seems disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake and West stand with their arms around their respecti daughters, Kristen and Marsha. The girls squirm and giggl politely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teasing Marsha) Your dad and I aren't sure you and  Kristen should go on the YC Convention  tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wes plays along:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Kristen, that's a long  trip to be on a bus with all those  boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean those creeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are more chaperones than boys  anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every family is in place. The social order is complete:  grandfather, parents, children, grandchildren. The long t is stacked high with salads, casseroles, and vegetables. The diners turn their heads toward Jake who stands at the far end of the table, his closed fists pressed against th tabletop. He lowers his head in prayer. One of the mothers, looking at her son, Lenard, quickly p the blanket off his head. The CAMERA TRACKS ACROSS the table toward Jake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We thank the Lord for bringing this  family together at graduation time.  We ask Thee to watch over this family  and keep us together in the coming  year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two cars are parked in the driveway of Van Dorn's suburba ranch-style home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marsha sits on the bed as Kristen finishes packing her  suitcase. The items include: a bright red sweater, jeans, underclot Tampax, and a Bible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake, Wes and Anne wait in the spotless dining area. Haro Jay looks in the refrigerator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Anne) Sis, would you check if Kristen has  everything packed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne nods and walks into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to go for coffee after we  send the girls off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Thanks anyway. I've got to get  over to the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne wants to make sure you come  over for dinner Sunday. With Kristen  gone you'll be all alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake nods. Kristen, wearing a light blue sweater and skirt, emerges  from the bedroom. She smiles demurely. Her suitcase is in her hand. Jake, for a moment, feels a  sharp twinge of loss. A foreboding of the day when Kriste fully grown, will leave his house for good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parents watch their children board a snow-covered bus out Twelfth St. Church. A banner across the side of the bus r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAND RAPIDS, MICH. -- BELLFLOWER, CALIF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the parents, working folk long accustomed to the  brutal Michigan winters, wear heavy overcoats, bearskin c fur-lined gloves and galoshes. Jake, bare-headed and wearing a thin topcoat over his sui waits with Kristen, Marsha, Wes and Anne. Harold Jay pelt the side of the bus with a snowball. MRS. STEENSMA, one of the trip counselors, reads off the  youngsters' names as they board the bus:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Daverman, DeBeer, DeBoer, DeJong,  DeVries...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marsha kisses her parents goodbye and heads toward the bu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...Vander Ark, Vander Hoven, Vander  Keen, Van Dorn, Van Dyke, E., Van  Dyke, S...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Kristen hears her name she starts toward the bus, th stops, comes back and gives her father a farewell kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care of yourself, Kristen. I  love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you need anything, just call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, amid horn-honking and farewells, the bus pulls awa from the curb and heads down the snowy street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sigh of relief goes up from the adolescent conventionee wheew! There are a few isolated cries of "We're on our wa A teenager instantly flips on his transistor RADIO to met ROCK. Once away from home, these kids, like all kids, are the children of 1976. The old family glue doesn't hold. T live in the world of rock and television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Workmen fashion table legs on a wood lathe. In another pa of the factory, laborers assemble chair frames. Jake walks along the assembly line with MARY, a well-dres attractive employee about twenty-five. They turn a corner and step into a display area where a set features the Van Dorn Co.'s new modular office designs. Mary shows Jake the set for his approval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this all the display space we can  get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to get more, but this is the  limit. The De Vries line has the  same area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is a cool, efficient display designer. Jake studies patch of bright blue on the right wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think of this... ah,  shade of blue, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like it, Mr. Van Dorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think it's a little too...  bright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. But if you want me to  tone it down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. I wouldn't hire a display  designer if I didn't trust her taste.  Maybe we should bring in more of  that shade. Perhaps a stripe across  the back wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures. Gently, relentlessly, Jake manipulates Mary. He does not  wish to impose his taste on her but, through calculated  argument, will get her to accept his views. It's only a m of time before he wears her down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that would be much too  overpowering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, overpowering. That was the  word I was looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sensing his ploy) Mr. Van Dorn, I've worked on the  color scheme for weeks. I think it's  just right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that shade of blue called?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pavonine. It's the same tint as the  stripe in the fabric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake bends down and examines the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you still going with that fella  that teaches at Grand Valley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He's a nice guy. Don't lose  him. Maybe we could tone down this  stripe a bit. It's a little...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (catching on) Overpowering?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gives in) Okay, Mr. Van Dorn, I think we could  knock that Pavonine blue a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure it's all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I think it'll look better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you say so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary watches him a moment and thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kristen went on that convention today,  didn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mildly surprised) Yeah. How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake lies in bed, sleeping. Blue light falls across his f He is dreaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A row of church buses are parked in the lot of First Chri Reformed Church, Bellflower, California. They have come from the various other Christian Reformed  communities around the country: Zeeland, Michigan, Midlan Park, New Jersey, Sioux Center, Iowa, Ripon, California. Clusters of youths sit on the church steps and spacious l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand-lettered poster on an easel reads: "Today's Topic: Doctrine -- Relevant or Old-Fashioned?" A slight, pretty GIRL about fifteen stands up before the  discussion group. She wears an Elton John T-shirt and nam tag. She holds her Bible with both hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even though the doctrinal standards  were written a long time ago, I think  they are more relevant than ever.  Especially in this age of  permissiveness and "anything goes..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kristen and Marsha stand near a tree. Kristen is wearing red sweater and jeans. Nearby, a group of boys sit in a circle on the grass tell jokes and listening to metal rock on a transistor radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to Knott's Berry Farm with  him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He asked me. You going with anybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever play Chicken?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teasing) You never heard of that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Com'on, tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, a boy goes like this, see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Using her finger, Marsha traces a looping oval around  Kristen's right breast, starting at the neck, working dow to the midriff, and back up her left side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, each time he comes in closer,  like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marsha traces another circle inside the first one. She dr a narrowing spiral around Kristen's breast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) He keeps coming closer until you say  "Chicken." Then he stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls giggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and Jerry do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Steensma steps out onto the lawn and calls to Kriste and Marsha:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kristen, Marsha! Time for your  discussion group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grudgingly) Oh, all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And put your name tags back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls pull their name tags out of their jeans and cli them on as they walk back toward the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVEREND VANTIL, a stately man about fifty, stands at the pulpit. The front of the church is plain and stark, adorn only by a large wooden cross. The Christian Reformed Church is not one which believes i emotional appeals or confessions. It is a religion of  scripture, creed and doctrine. Reverend Vantil, dressed i black, addresses the congregation as if he were a busines And his business is sin, guilt and redemption. He speaks calmly and powerfully. The church echoes with t weight of his words:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...our study of the Heidelberg  Catechism, reading today Lords Day  number one, question and answer one  and two: (reads) Q: What is your only comfort in life  and death? A: That I, body and soul,  both in life and death, am not my  own but belong unto my faithful Savior  Jesus Christ. Q: How many things are  necessary to know to live and die  happily? A: Three: the first, how  great my sin and misery are; the  second, how I am delivered from all  my sin and misery; the third, how I  am to be thankful to God for such  deliverance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. The CAMERA TRACKS UP the aisle as the congregation rises to sing the doxology. Jake stands with his sister a brother-in-law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The parishioners, fighting off the winter cold, work thei way to their cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake, Wes, Anne and Harold Jay pass dishes around the De  Jong's dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...as soon as the service starts,  the ushers all go off to Big Boy's  and have coffee...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I'll get it. (gets up) So that when someone like Mrs. Van  Dorn in a wheelchair needs some help  there's nobody there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks into the living room. After a moment, Anne walk back into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) It's for you, Jake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Van Dorn excuses himself, walks into the living room and  answers the phone. His VOICE can be HEARD in the backgrou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Well, I just hope I don't get old  and in a wheelchair and have to depend  on the ushers to help me out of  church. (to Harold Jay) You would never let that happen to  your mother, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold Jay nods and keeps eating. He's used to this. A moment later, Jake, his face drained of color, walks ba into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Jake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wes, Anne, come here a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wes and Anne step into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was Mrs. Steensma calling from  California. (a beat) Kristen's disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kristen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't know. They were having  some recreation deal out at Knott's  Berry Farm and Kristen wasn't there  when they got back to the bus and  they couldn't find her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have they called the police?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Marsha there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. She's quite upset. I'm going  to fly out today. They want me to  bring some pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come with you. Let me pack some  things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A United Jet lands. Marsha's VOICE is HEARD from the foll scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake and Wes sit near Marsha. Mrs. Steensma stands nearby

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...They have a ride called "The Great  White Knuckler", a roller coaster.  Last time I saw Kristen was standing  over there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why was she alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Mrs. Steensma. Marsha is hiding something: Sh was off necking when Kristen disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was she alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told this to the policeman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They had met an older boy earlier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she wasn't with him when I saw  her last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tried to give the officers a  description. It was nothing out of  the ordinary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DETECTIVE BURROWS, of Missing Persons, carries Kristen's  picture and a form Jake has filled out into the "Runaway  Room". Jake and Wes follow. One long wall is covered with tacked-up snapshots of pers (mostly young) the police are looking for. Each snapshot attached to a small form listing the missing person's nam age, home and so forth. A sign above the photo montage re "Have you seen this person?" Burrows tacks up Kristen's picture on the Missing Persons wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy your daughter was talking to  didn't work at the park. We've  interviewed everybody there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But is she, has...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no evidence of any foul play  at present. I hope she's just a  runaway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something wrong here. Kristen  is not the type of girl to just up  and leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I hope she's a runaway. Better  that than she just disappears like  so many others do. Sometimes they  turn up years later, sometimes not.  A lot of crimes go unreported,  unknown. These are realities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two officers have been assigned to  the case. I can't keep them on  indefinitely, but we'll go through  every lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another day, Jake and Wes, wearing different clothes, wal with ANDY MAST, a private investigator, down an L.A. stre They walk silently, Mast, forty, a stocky man in a wrinkl suit, looks like he's been up all night. He probably has. Mast motions to a coffee shop and they enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mast, slouching in the booth, sips his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those cops, like all cops, are  intelligent enough, but they are  masters of de-ductive reason. That  is, you ask them what three and two  are they'll tell you five, but if  you ask them what five is, they go  blank. That's spec-u-lative reasoning,  and that's where I come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what do they know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dogshit. Worse yet, they don't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So then, Mr. Mast...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What do you have to offer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me ask you a personal question,  a painful one. The first of many.  Tell me, was your daughter the kind  of girl to run around, to, ah, play  practical jokes, maybe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Van Dorn answers him with a cold stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) No, I didn't think she was. Let me  get the picture here. Let me guess.  She was an absolutely clean girl, a  model daughter, she never had  rebellious or impure thoughts, she  didn't fuck around...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I was you, Mr. Mast, I'd watch my  language.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm a private detective, Van  Dorn, you want to hire a choir boy  you can go back to Grand Rapids.  I've been to that scumbag town. It's  full of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cold) Who's paying you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (backtracks) As I was saying, I'll pick up the  thread. There's a number of ways I  can go. There's not much you can do  here. Stay if you want. Maybe it'd  be better if you went back home. Go  through Kristen's personal stuff.  Ask around, maybe she knew somebody  out here. (a beat) Look, I do this a lot. I work at a  minimum rate of $750.00 a week. It  may seem like a lot of money to you,  but it ain't. You could hire cheaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose. But I'll tell you, Jake,  I'm like a little animal. When I get  my teeth into something I never let  go. If your daughter's here, I'll  track her down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Jake sits at his desk, staring into empty space. -- Jake looks through his wife's personal effects in the  bureau. The room is unchanged. -- Jake, his arms folded, stands outside church. A fellow parishioner is speaking to him; Jake doesn't seem to be  listening. Mast's VOICE comes over a long distance connection:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilgrim, this is Andy. I'm in Phoenix. (a beat) Yeah, it looks that way. I don't  know why. I'm going south, then maybe  fly over to Nogales. (a beat) I think so. (a beat) Yeah, I picked up your check at  Western Union.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Jake gets out of his car and looks down the street of strange town. A nearby sign reads: Minneapolis National T -- Jake walks into a greasy spoon. Ahead of him, her back turned, sits a girl who looks like Kristen. She turns as approaches; it is another girl, another runaway. He apolo and walks away. OVER this SCENE, we HEAR Van Dorn's telephoned VOICE:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I was up in Minneapolis. Somebody  responded to my ad. Said there was a  girl who looked like Kristen there.  But it wasn't her. The police haven't  found anything? (a beat) It don't look good. I don't know.  Maybe she's dead already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spring has returned to Grand Rapids. The maples are in bl and the chairs have been set out on the long porch of Wes Jong's house. We HEAR Mast's telephone VOICE as Jake gets out of his ca and enters the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took a side trip to Mexico City.  It was just a long shot, but it didn't  pay off. So I'm back in L.A. (a beat) Yeah, the money came on time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake, carrying a wrapped present, walks into the kitchen. Anne, Joe and John, sitting around the table, greet him a he enters. A large birthday cake sits in the center of th table. Jake says, "Hi, Sis," and nods to the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Marsha?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Marsha!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marsha walks in, smiling when she sees her uncle:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Jake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gives her present) Happy birthday, Marsha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake and Joe sit on chairs on the porch. Wes and Willem r on the rickety swing. All are drinking coffee, finishing  pieces of birthday cake and enjoying a fine spring Sunday Harold Jay watches quietly from the railing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sets down plate) Spring's early. Without a frost we'll  have a good year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not as good as last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord's been good to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the street, two junior high boys, pushing their bi follow two female classmates. The girls dressed in tight  halters and shorts try to ignore them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never had to make a dishonest dollar  in my life. Never cheated an employee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you? They're all your  relatives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lord got his share, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe gets up to refill his coffee cup. Wes turns to Jake, is watching the couples across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your business, Jake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (absentminded) Pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should come around more often.  You haven't been around for weeks.  Anne complains she doesn't see you  anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake, looking away, doesn't answer. Wes contemplates some he's been planning to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You can't dwell on Kristen all the  time, Jake. Sometimes we can't  understand the Lord's ways. He is  testing you. You have to have faith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake turns and looks back at Wes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you? (a beat) Could you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks away again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake is at his desk when the PHONE RINGS. He picks up the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Van Dorn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you? The connection sounds  very good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm back in Grand Rapids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In G.R.? Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you meet me in about an hour? At  the Pantlind Hotel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a meeting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you paying me for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake and Mast walk out of the Pantlind and walk up Monroe Avenue. The heart of Grand Rapids, like that of many Mid- western cities, is a ghost town. The major businesses hav one by one gone broke or moved out to the suburban malls, leaving the core of the city to cut-rate stores, parking  lots and federally-subsidized government buildings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This used to be a real city. I was  here about fifteen years ago.  Embezzlement case. It was always a  little religious for my taste, but  at least it was a city. With a  downtown and all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you found out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got some news. Your daughter's  all right. At least I think she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever seen any, ah,  pornographic movies, Jake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what a "hardcore" movie  is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's like a stag film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. You ever seen any of those?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're legal now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (a beat) All over. Even here in Grand Rapids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a little stall theatre up  here. (gestures) It's closed now, but I'm borrowing  it for an hour. I think there's  something you'd better see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake is uncomfortably seated in the dingy thirty-seat the Mast walks back from the projection booth as the film sta He sits next to Van Dorn. We slowly TRACK INTO Jake's fac as the color drains from it. O.S. We HEAR groans and the  sounds of flesh on flesh. We TRACK SLOWLY INTO the film itself: A 16mm hardcore short on a simple, but classic theme -- r Two young men force a young, unwilling girl to submit to  their desires. The girl -- Kristen -- nude, tries to get of a wrinkled bed but is restrained by the long arm of a  languid, long-haired nude youth. Another young man, weari only pink elastic shorts, steps into the frame and takes  Kristen into his arms. The quality of the action is quite low; the young men pos and overact in the manner of high school dramatics.  Occasionally, the action stops while the actors receive c from an off-screen director. Grunts and groans are dubbed into the screen action. Only Kristen's performance lends a note of credibility to the proceedings. She is genuinely disoriented or frighten or both. She's not play acting. For one frightening moment, Kristen, regaining full  consciousness, fights back, but the youth in pink shorts  slaps her into submission. Her eyes turn pleadingly towar the camera. The first youth laughs and takes Kristen into his arms. T youth in the pink shorts kneels on the edge of the bed an instructs Kristen to remove his shorts. As she begins to this, the first youth fucks her from the rear. As the film ends, Jake sinks his head into his hands, spe to himself. It's almost as if we're hearing his thoughts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can't be. Why me? What have I  done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking up, he says softly, then louder:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Turn it off. (a beat) Turn it off. (a beat) Turn it off! (a beat) Turn it off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only then does Jake realize that the film has already bee shut off and he's sitting alone in the quiet theatre. Mast stands by the exit. Jake gets up and walks toward hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake catches up with Mast in the small lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aggressively) Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you get that film?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake backs Mast from one side of the lobby to the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bought it at a store in L.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who made it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mast calms him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. Slow down. A film like this,  16mm, cost two three hundred dollars,  sold outright, shown in peep machines,  maybe theatres, maybe not, is almost  impossible to track. 'Nobody' makes  it; 'nobody' shows it; 'nobody' sees  it. It's like it doesn't even exist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it called?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was called 'Slave of Love' when I  bought it. Next time it's sold, it'll  be called something else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the police...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police? They know less than you  do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think she's safe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Probably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like this, don't you. Showing  me... this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate it. But you gotta know, buddy. (thinks) A lot of strange things happen in  this world. Things you don't know  about in Grand Rapids. Things you  don't want to know about. Doors that  should never be opened. I've known  more about this sort of thing than a  man should. Don't ask me why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I'm going back to L.A. today. I'll  track this film down, if I can. I'll  find her. But I can't make any  promises. I don't know what she'll  be like when I find her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake, pale, looks away. Mast attempts to give him a comfo embrace. Jake pushes him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Van Dorn sleeps fitfully. Blue light falls across his  contorted body. He's dreaming again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sleazy Santa Monica Boulevard motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A porn film is being shot in a tacky motel room furnished with a pink circular water bed, a lime-brown shag rug, an peeling red felt wallpaper. An oil painting of a seagull flight adds a touch of class. The small set is crowded with technicians and onlookers. harried collegiate filmmakers wear scruffy jeans and T-sh The onlookers, more refined, sport double knit suits. Two girls and a middle-aged man lie on the pink satin she Beach towels protect them from the unheated water bed. On of the girls, NIKI, has a long blonde wig and looks about nineteen. The makeup girl hurriedly dabs some last minute cosmetic the second girl's breast. A young man in a UCLA T-shirt p up the peeling wallpaper above the bed. Random VOICES ECHO around the set. The DIRECTOR, a studen filmmaker, tries to bring the set to order. BILL RAMADA, 40, the Producer, watches silently from the  b.g. He's in charge here. He wears gabardine slacks and a Gucci shirt. His Assistant, KURT, 25, stands by his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clapping hands) All right, kids, let's get back to  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actors, to your positions, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Niki, the SECOND GIRL and the Actor remove their towels a form a contorted triangular position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you get this bed any warmer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring another light over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My ass is freezing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your ass is always freezing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Second Girl coaxes her male partner into tumescence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Action. Rolling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wallpaper's peeling again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. Keep shooting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crouching, the Director approaches his actors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) All right, Niki, you come around  this way and swing your legs around  his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Director pleads with outstretched hands. His acting  workshop courses have not been in vain. Lowering his voic he coaxes Niki into the proper mood:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) All right, Niki, you're lying back  now, yes, just taking it easy, just  enjoying your body, yes, you're  thinking about your father, your  mind is open and free...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mast walks into the rear of the room and looks around unt he spots Ramada.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Okay, now Bennie, you turn over and  lick her belly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramada recognizes Mast as he walks toward him and motions for him to follow. They step into an adjoining room. The Director's instruct drone in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (friendly) Hey, piss-head, what brings you  around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to get uppity with  me, Bill. I remember when you was  running that car wash and couldn't  make it go. And what was that other  thing you tried? A Dairy Queen? Went  busted too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least I improved myself. What's  up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mast takes out a snapshot of Kristen. In the background t Director yells, "Cut."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to take a look at this  girl here. She's been in some porn  stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at photo) No, Andy. Don't know the kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look again, Billy-boy. This is jail  bait. Could get you in a lotta  trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes head) Nope never saw her before. (calls to assistant) Kurt, come over here. Don't use  underage kids. Wouldn't touch 'em  for all the cow shit in Mexico. (as Kurt steps over) You recognize this piece of wool,  Kurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes head) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry couldn't help you, Andy. (to Kurt) How'd the shot go? They about ready  to start again? (to Mast) You can come watch if you want, Andy.  Just don't hassle anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mast shrugs, tucks the photo in his pocket and follows Ra and Kurt back onto the set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake leaves the factory in the middle of the afternoon, g in his car and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake walks into his bedroom, pulls a suitcase out of the  closet and throws it on the bed. He is motivated now. A decision has been made. He throws in his shirts and socks. A travel clock. Pictur of Kristen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake is on the phone. His voice is hard and determined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Jake. I'm going out of town  for a while. (a beat) No, I don't know when I'll be back.  No, there's nothing wrong. Can you  keep things running? (a beat) Don't ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: United jet lands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Van Dorn, dressed and ready to go, walks out of the Holly Holiday Inn and over to the parking lot. Checking a city map one final time, he gets into his late model rented green Pontiac and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake seems a new man; he's in charge now. To a man like J Van Dorn, a man from the Midwest, a self-made man, all is possible once you're in control. There are no ambiguities no conundrums, no labyrinths; only problems. And problems once understood, lead only to solutions. All one needs is the will and the intellect to pursue tho solutions. Jake looks at the note pad on the seat. It reads: Andy Mast  Apt. #3-A  14316 Chandler Blvd.,  Van Nuys, Calif.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drives up Highland, past the freeway and over the hill

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Van Dorn parks in front of the Elite V Apartments. Jake stops in front of the room, re-checks the number, an knocks. There's no immediate answer. Hearing some commotion in th room, Jake stops, listens. He peeks through the partially curtained window. Inside, he sees Mast banging away with a TEENAGE GIRL on sofa. Jake is curious, then outraged. He tries the door. It ope Inside, Mast and his teenage companion scramble for their clothes. The girl calls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the cops, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake strides into Mast's apartment. Mast, his belt unbuckled, puts on his shirt. The Teenage  Girl, pulling a Grateful Dead T-shirt over her head, look at Jake and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not pausing to speak, Jake pushes Mast against the sofa.  Reaching down, he pulls the detective up by the collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? You son-of-a- bitch! I've been paying you every  week for three months and you've  been out here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm splitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake turns as the girl vanishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't cheated you, Pilgrim. This  is research, damn it! That girl could  have told us something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Research, my ass. I suppose these  are the 'extra expenses' I've been  paying for? And in the middle of the  morning, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mast pulls himself away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, fuck off. You should stay where  you belong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out. Get out of here, Goddammit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mast picks up his shoes and says half-apologetically:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only human, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this is my apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mast shrugs. There's no reasoning with Van Dorn. He pause at the door and looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You prick. You ass-hole prick. You  can find your own Goddamn daughter  now. (stops; looks at door) I'm not even smart enough to lock my  own fucking door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mast closes the door behind him. Van Dorn looks around th apartment. It's calm now. On the desk are Mast's briefcase and papers. Looking through Mast's files, Jake finds pages and pages notes and information about his daughter's disappearance. Names, places, dates. Lists of massage parlors, sex shops porn bookshops. The names of owners, managers, filmmakers Interviews with street girls, cops, landlords. Plus snapshots of Kristen as she once was and 8x10 frame  enlargements from "Slave of Love," her hardcore film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake has spread Mast's papers and photographs across the  floor of his Holiday Inn motel room. His collar open, his tie loosened, Van Dorn squats over t notes and interviews. He studies his find. It includes: -- sex ads from various local papers. Some are crossed ou others circled, others checked. -- a list of massage parlors and sex shops under the head "possible K was here." -- An L.A. Times newspaper clipping about "Bill Ramada, L Porn Movie Mogul." It features a photo of Ramada on his w out of court. -- a sleazy porn mag article about "Parlor Girls: Hustlin and Loving."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Van Dorn drives through the crowded streets of Los Angele tenderloin. He cruises down Santa Monica, up Western, alo Hollywood and back down to Santa Monica. He passes row upon row of garish adult bookstores, massag parlors and porn theatres. He passes model shops, topless bars, "erotic motels," and peep shows. Teenage girls stand in the red neon shadows, calling out passing strangers. Drag queens and leather boys cruise th sidewalks. Jet black pimps, sporting high heels and make  coats, stroll from one massage parlor to another. The sou of Latin jazz comes from one doorway; soul disco from ano L.A.P.D. black and whites patrol the streets. Occasionall a uniformed officer leans out to hassle a passing pimp or hooker. He drives on. The sex shops have names like "The Sexual  Catharthis Center," "Pandora's Box," "The Institute of Or Love," "69 Club," "The Church of Spiritual Sexuality," "T Participating Center of Sexual Experience," "Mother's Fun Palace," "The Hot Box." A zoo of lusts. Jake looks at the seat beside him, checking Mast's list o massage parlors and sex stores with the notation, "possib K was here."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Van Dorn pulls to the curb and parks his car. Ahead is th plexiglass lettered sign of the Adonis bookstore. Jake locks his car, buttons his suit coat and walks towar the bookstore. He hesitates a moment, then enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake steps into the bookstore and looks cautiously from s to side. His expression is stern, withdrawn, as if suppressing som physical pain. He finds nothing titillating about this wo for him it is simply evil. Neither is he shocked. Has he been taught: "For every imagination of man's heart is onl evil continually"? An improbable assortment of men peruse the long racks of  pornographic books and magazines. A young MALE TELLER sit next to a cash register atop a high counter. Below him, a display case features sexual paraphernalia and films. A s radio softly plays Muzak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty cents admission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fifty cents admission. It's  applicable to a purchase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake fishes in his pocket, comes up with a couple quarter and places them on the counter. The Teller gives him a to in return. Van Dorn walks down one row and up another. The explicit  titles and magazine covers leap out at him: "Cropped  Crotches," "Teenage Obedience Lesson," "Mouthful of Cock, "Hogtie." Many of the magazine covers feature obviously  underage girls. He eases his way past a butch young man  looking at magazines in the gay section. Screwing up his courage, Jake steps back to the counter. He tries but cannot avert his eyes from the grotesque sex novelties in the case. Dildos, some small, some huge and  gross, looking more like instruments of torture than plea Stimulators, vibrators, spiked ticklers. Penis enlargers. Leather paddles, whips, masks, rubber vaginas, fuck faces masturbators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a, ah, film called 'Slave  of Love?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we got is just these here. (gestures) What you see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a short film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all about the same. You want  something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake looks momentarily at the boxes of 16mm film. A coupl titles read "Office Party," and "Butt Banger."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Van Dorn pulls a folded 8x10 out of his vest pocket. It's glossy frame enlargement from "Slave of Love" folded to r only Kristen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is from the movie I was talking  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wondered if you had ever seen this  film or this woman... (points) ...right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That girl? No, never saw her. I don't  know anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just trying to find... (getting testy) Who owns this store?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Look, man, if you're  looking for somebody maybe you ought  to see the cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know nothing, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake, realizing he's getting nowhere, pockets his photogr and turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You don't want anything for your  fifty cents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Teller places two quarters on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Take your fifty cents back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, take it. I don't want your Goddamn  fifty cents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake places the token on the counter, takes his quarters walks back out into the neon night. The Teller turns to n one in particular and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) It's one of those Legion of Decency  guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Van Dorn walks west on Santa Monica Boulevard. The entran to Wild Mary's is formed by the larger-than-life painted  rear view of a bent over woman. Her long legs flank eithe side of the open passageway. A young man in a cowboy shirt repeats monotoned litany to passersby:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Free information. Free information  inside. Come in and get free  information. Free information. Free  information inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake pauses in front of the California Cowboy, then enter passing through Wild Mary's muscled thighs.
